moves: 1. e4 e5 2. Nf3 Nc6 3. Bb5 a6 4. Ba4 Nf6 5. O-O Be7 6. Re1 b5 7. Bb3 O-O 8. a4
comment: Adams does play the Marshall Gambit and many people don't like to play against it, so they play such moves as 8. a4 to avoid it. Still, that doesn't end Black's attempts to play actively.

moves: 1. e4 e5 2. Nf3 Nc6 3. Bb5 a6 4. Ba4 Nf6 5. O-O Be7 6. Re1 b5 7. Bb3 O-O 8. a4 Bb7 9. d3 Re8 10. Nc3 b4 11. Nd5 Na5 12. Nxe7+ Qxe7 13. Ba2
comment: White's Pe4 is under assault, so it's difficult for him to consider d3-d4. However, White has the two bishops, so at some point he'll want (or need) open lines and seek out targets.

moves: 1. e4 e5 2. Nf3 Nc6 3. Bb5 a6 4. Ba4 Nf6 5. O-O Be7 6. Re1 b5 7. Bb3 O-O 8. a4 Bb7 9. d3 Re8 10. Nc3 b4 11. Nd5 Na5 12. Nxe7+ Qxe7 13. Ba2 d5
1. e4 e5 2. Nf3 Nc6 3. Bb5 a6 4. Ba4 Nf6 5. O-O Be7 6. Re1 b5 7. Bb3 O-O 8. a4 Bb7 9. d3 Re8 10. Nc3 b4 11. Nd5 Na5 12. Nxe7+ Qxe7 13. Ba2 d5 14. Bg5 dxe4 15. dxe4 Rad8 16. Qe2 h6 17. Bxf6 Qxf6
comment: This position is much more balanced and unexciting. Each has a little pressure on the other's central pawn and only Black has slightly weakened queen-side pawns.

moves: 1. e4 e5 2. Nf3 Nc6 3. Bb5 a6 4. Ba4 Nf6 5. O-O Be7 6. Re1 b5 7. Bb3 O-O 8. a4 Bb7 9. d3 Re8 10. Nc3 b4 11. Nd5 Na5 12. Nxe7+ Qxe7 13. Ba2 d5 14. Bg5 dxe4 15. dxe4 Rad8 16. Qe2 h6 17. Bxf6 Qxf6 18. Rad1 Qe7 19. h3 g6 20. Qe3 Kg7 21. Bd5 Bxd5 22. exd5
comment: This change in pawn structure makes Black's queen-side look disjointed and weak, but it also appears to free Black's king-side pawns to advance (if he would dare) .

moves: 1. e4 e5 2. Nf3 Nc6 3. Bb5 a6 4. Ba4 Nf6 5. O-O Be7 6. Re1 b5 7. Bb3 O-O 8. a4 Bb7 9. d3 Re8 10. Nc3 b4 11. Nd5 Na5 12. Nxe7+ Qxe7 13. Ba2 d5 14. Bg5 dxe4 15. dxe4 Rad8 16. Qe2 h6 17. Bxf6 Qxf6 18. Rad1 Qe7 19. h3 g6 20. Qe3 Kg7 21. Bd5 Bxd5 22. exd5 Nc4 23. Qb3 Na5 24. Qe3 Nc4 25. Qb3 Na5
comment: Both seemed a little nervous about starting any major plan of offense, so they conceded to a draw.
